meanings.definition: The art of effective or persuasive speaking or writing.
meanings.sent1: Her use of rhetoric in the speech captivated the audience.
meanings.sent2: The politician's rhetoric swayed many voters to support him.
meanings.sent3: The teacher's rhetoric about the importance of studying paid off with improved grades.
meanings.sent4: The rhetoric of the advertisement painted a vivid picture of the product's benefits.
meanings.sent5: His rhetoric was so powerful that it stayed in the minds of the listeners long after the speech ended.

meanings.definition: Language designed to have a persuasive or impressive effect on its audience.
meanings.sent1: The poet's use of rhetoric in his verses stirred deep emotions in the readers.
meanings.sent2: The marketing team crafted compelling rhetoric to attract more customers.
meanings.sent3: The comedian's rhetoric had the audience laughing uncontrollably.
meanings.sent4: The rhetoric of the novel painted a vivid picture of the protagonist's struggles.
meanings.sent5: The rhetoric of the speech left a lasting impact on all who heard it.

meanings.definition: The study of writing or speaking as a means of communication or persuasion.
meanings.sent1: In her rhetoric class, she learned how to structure persuasive arguments.
meanings.sent2: The rhetoric course helped students improve their communication skills.
meanings.sent3: The professor's rhetoric about the importance of practice resonated with the students.
meanings.sent4: The rhetoric of the workshop inspired participants to express themselves more effectively.
meanings.sent5: The rhetoric of the debate team members impressed the judges with their eloquence.
